p: Climate change and its interactions with other factors have been recently identified as important contributors to the amphibian diversity crisis 4 9 10 11 12 13. Because of their ectothermic nature, highly permeable skin, and complex life cycles, amphibians strongly depend on specific temperature ranges, moisture, and precipitation 1 14 15, factors which are fundamentally affected by climate change 16 17. It has been shown that changes in climate, especially temperature, can alter breeding phenology 15 18 19 20 21 22, body condition 23 and disease susceptibility 11 24 25 of amphibians, but how and to what extent climatic changes may affect amphibians in hibernation has remained equivocal.
